speaker: the narrator

utterance: Yes, suh; mistis tell me to come and stop right by two big rocks in front of a red sto'. Dyah's de sto', but I b'lieve dee done move dem rocks. I see 'em heah dis mornin' when I went by!

utterance: They are there still, but those carriages hide them.
speaker: the narrator

utterance: Yes, suh; I never see sich folks in my life. Dee ain' got no manners in de worl'! Dee 'll put dee kerridge right in yo' way, don' keer what you do! And dee won' git out to save yo' life. Mistis told me to be here by three, an'-

utterance: Why, it 's only half-past one now,
speaker: the narrator

utterance: Yes, suh; but I likes to be sort o' promptual in town! See dem kerridges by dem rocks now! I jes want to git in dyah once, an' I boun' dee oon git me out agin b'fo' my mistises come. I don' like dese city ways, an' I never did like a citified nigger nohow! I got a right good ways to go, too.
speaker: the driver

utterance: How far do you live from town?
speaker: the narrator

utterance: In and about eighteen miles, suh. I start b'fo' light dis mornin'. I comes from Colonel Dale's ole place. 'Hill-an'-Dale' dee calls it.

utterance: Tell me something of old Mr. Miles?
speaker: narrator

utterance:
Miles? Old Mr. Miles? Basham Miles?
What about him? He used to be a member of the Bar, and the best lawyer at it. He argued the case of Calthorp against Brown. Have you ever read his argument? It 's the greatest exposition of Where's the report? Give me that book, will you?
speaker: old members of the Bar

utterance: No. But why did he leave the Bar? Was there ever anything-ah,-out of the way about him-any story of-ah-?
speaker: narrator

utterance:
About Miles?
Miles? Why, no! Who says there was? He was one of the highest men who was ever at the Bar. He left the Bar because-[Hunting through the book.] He gave it up because— Which?-Ah! here it is!-Listen to this.Why, he gave it up because he did n't need it-had plenty of money without it. I'd have done the same thing if I had been in his fix.
I believe there was a woman had something to do with it-jilted him or something, and he never got over it.-Ah! here it is! [Reading.] 'Calthorp's Executor against Brown's Administrator and others.'-Listen to this!
speaker: old members of the Bar

utterance: Why, sir, John Marshall could not have beat that! He made the Court reverse itself by that argument, and established that for the law! And I want to tell you that 's not the easiest thing in the world to do, young man.
speaker: old members of the Bar

utterance: the rigor of the game,
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: proposing so dull a duty
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: An old man like myself has to live in the past. My friends are all there.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance:
They are the true philosophers. When you find a sincere man in a book, sir, cherish him. He is like a sincere man in life: you know him at once, and he is rara avis. The old ones were sincere.
Shakespeare, of course because he knew the Human Soul, and could not help it. It was as if he had stood face to face with God, and dared not tell anything but Truth.
Milton was sincere, because he was a fanatic; Bacon, because he was too wise not to be.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance:
Nearly all posing, writing either for popularity or for some other miserable end.
Why, sir, I have piles of them. Goldsmith, for all his fopperies, was sincere, because he was a poet. His pen inspired him. It was the key that turned on the divine fluid. Johnson said of him, you know, that no man was more foolish till he took up his pen, or more wise when he took it up. Wordsworth was always sincere for the same reason. They had a high idea of their profession, as poets and preachers must have.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: Do you not think he writes well?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Yes, sir, he writes vigorously,-I suppose you mean that,—but it is not English. I do not know just what to term it. It was a trick with him, a part of his pedantry. But when I want acerbity I prefer Swift.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: He is a kindly man, and has 'wrought in a sad sincerity.' But he preaches too much for me, and he is all texts. When I want preaching I go to church.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: At least, I do when I can find it.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: That is not so often these days.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance:
The Pulpit has lost its power, sir: thrown away its best prerogative-the gift of preaching. The Clergy no more preach with power, because they no more believe with strength.
Why should I go to hear a young man, of far less knowledge than myself, holding forth to worldly people worldly considerations to induce them to embrace a religion of which the founder preached the blessedness of Sorrow!
The poorest preacher, sir, is impressive so long as he believes himself the Minister of God. I may not accept his message, but if he believes in his mission I shall respect him. If, however, he questions his own credentials I will not listen to him.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: But I am getting to preaching myself. We were speaking of the Essayists?
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance:
After all, the best of these Essayists to me is the first, Plutarch; and next to him the second, Montaigne. Plutarch is as modern as if he had just written, because he knew Human Nature. Human Nature is always the same. Montaigne drew from Plutarch, and the others from Montaigne. They have all been pillaging him ever since he wrote.
Why, sir, I am enough like Montaigne to be his embodied spirit. When I read Montaigne I feel as if I were reading myself. It is a pleasure to me to know that they are the two which we have some grounds to believe Shakespeare read.
You cannot get a man nowadays to tell you what he really feels or thinks. Feeling has gone out of fashion. Every one is trying to repress his feeling, and he does not think at all. Convention has taken the place of Originality. Why, sir, we are all trying to say what we think our neighbor thinks.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: Young man, Domestic happiness is worth all the Fame in the world!
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: Lucky dog! I would rather be able to play marbles than to play monarch.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: the summer Basham Miles was so attentive to Betsey Green.
speaker: old lady

utterance: Why, don't you remember, that night I had on a lilac mull, and you had on a white embroidered muslin?
speaker: old lady

utterance: Oh, yes, to be sure!
speaker: old lady

utterance: My! my! How long ago that was!-And yet it seems only yesterday!
speaker: Malviny Gray

utterance: Yes, it was a long time ago!
speaker: Malviny Gray

utterance: What a handsome man Basham Miles was then!
speaker: old lady

utterance: I never thought so; there was always a self-consciousness about him which marred his looks to me.
speaker: Malviny Gray

utterance:
Oh, I think he was a perfect Adonis! I wonder if he has ever regretted not marrying?
I think he was really in love with Betsey.
speaker: old lady

utterance:
No, not he! He was too well satisfied with himself. I am very sure Betsey never thought he was in love with her.
I would n't give Burton Dale, with his kind old heart, for a hundred of him, with all his cleverness.
speaker: Malviny Gray

utterance: Yes, her health has been very poor ever since the birth of her last infant, and then her mother's death, just after Hill-andDale was sold, told greatly on her; so she does not get to see me as often as she did when she first came to live here, last spring.
speaker: old lady

utterance: I must go and see her.
speaker: Malviny Gray

utterance: I would have been before, but I walk so badly now, I find myself putting things off. She brought her youngest sister to see me not very long ago-very like Betsey! I could almost have thought it was Betsey herself as she sat by me and talked to me. You remember that way Betsey had of stroking your hand when she was sitting by you talking earnestly?
speaker: Malviny Gray

utterance: Elizabeth? Yes, she is like Betsey. But not so pretty.
speaker: old lady

utterance: I thought she was rather prettier; but then I see so badly these days. Good-bye; you must come again. Don't wait for me to come; I can't walk much, and-
speaker: Malviny Gray

utterance:
Oh, pshaw! Malviny Gray, you have been trading on those three months of superior age to me ever since we went to school to old Mr.
Persico when you were twelve years old, and I am not going to put up with it any longer.
You are as arrogant about it as Basham Miles used to be about his intellect! Good-bye.
speaker: old lady

utterance: She reminded me strongly of some one I knew once-of an old friend of mine. These resemblances are very curious.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: Difficulty?
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: Why, sir, when I was your age I knew every pretty girl in town!
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: Was she pretty?
speaker: narrator

utterance: I did not see her face.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Pretty! She was a beauty, sir! She looked like an angel. And she is a lady. I don't know that a man is a judge of the beauty of a person who runs after and catches his hat for him. What between rage and gratitude he is not in a very judicial temper. But she seemed to me a beauty; and she resembled one who was a beauty. Yes, sir, she was a beauty.
speaker: Basham Miles

speaker: Elizabeth Dale

utterance: I would not go so far as that, though they remind me a little of a poem of Sir Charles Sedley's: 'Not Celia that I juster am, Or better than the rest—' You remember that poem?
speaker: Elizabeth Dale

utterance: Even had I been a witch, sir, you would never have rescued me. You would have begun to bluster at the door and offer to fight all comers, and so would have been overwhelmed at once and never even have known my true friends who might have planned my rescue.
speaker: Elizabeth Dale

utterance: He has some very important business.

speaker: narrator

utterance: How do you do?

utterance:
Mrs. Hall, here is a gentleman to see you.
Can he come in?
speaker: Elizabeth Dale

utterance: Won't you walk in?
speaker: Elizabeth Dale

utterance: I am glad Mrs. Hall has so good a friend.
speaker: Elizabeth Dale

utterance: Fact is, suh, I 's mighty troubled 'bout him. He ain't gittin' no better: jes' gittin' punier an' punier. I don' b'lieve he 's gwine to last much longer.
speaker: William Kemp

utterance: He don' do nuttin' sep' set dyah all day in de big cheer. He use' to readread all de time, night an' day, but he don' eben do dat no longer!
speaker: William Kemp

utterance: Who is with him?
speaker: narrator

utterance:
D' ain' no-body wid him, suh. He won' have no-body. He never wuz no han' for havin' folks 'bout him pesterin' him, no-how,
-strange folks expressly; he would n' even have a doctor to come to see him, after old Dr. Thomas die. He used to come sometimes.
Since den he would n' have no-body; but me and Jane got him to le' me go and ax Dr. Williams to come an' see him, an' he say he pretty sick, an' gi' him some physic. But he would n'
teck it, suh! He say he gwine die anyhow, an'
he ain't gwine take no nasty physic. He got de bottle dyah now in he room, an' it jes full as 't was when I bring it from de drug-sto'!
speaker: William Kemp

utterance:
Yes, suh, wish you would; maybe he would see yo', and maybe he won't. He mighty fond o' you. He won' see many folks. Several ladies been to inquire after him, and Mrs.
Miller, she and annur' lady too, sen' him things; but he won' see no-body, an' he won'
eat nuttin'. I 's right smartly troubled about him, suh.
speaker: William Kemp

utterance: I tell you, suh, a man ought to have wife and chillern to take keer on him when he git ole, any 'ow!
speaker: William Kemp

utterance: They fail you at the crucial time, sir. They forsake you or bore you.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: Yes, sir, they are!
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance:
This book alone has held out.
This has not deserted me. I have read something of all the philosophies, but none has the spirituality and power that I find in certain parts of this. No wonder Scott said, 'There is but one book.'
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: That volume was my mother's. She died with it on her pillow, as she had lived with it in her heart.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: He is going to die.
speaker: Dr. Williams

utterance: Well, Doctor, ought not he to have some one to stay with him?
speaker: narrator

utterance:
Of course he ought, and I have told him so. But he is a very difficult man to deal with. What can you do with him?
He is going to die anyhow, and knows it, and he says the idea of any one staying in the house with him makes him nervous. I have told his man William to stay in the house tonight, but I don't know that he will let him do it.
speaker: Dr. Williams

utterance: He won' have no-body roun' him 't all, suh. Two or three people been heah to see him to-day, but he won' see none on 'em; he 'll hardly see me, an' he tell me when bedtime come, jes to shet up as ushal, an' let him 'lone.
speaker: William Kemp

utterance: But I 'm gwine to stay in dat house tonight, don' keer what he say!
speaker: William Kemp

utterance: Is your mother living?
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance:
That is the greatest blessing a man can have. Mine died when I was ten years old, and I have never gotten over the loss. I have missed her every hour since. Had she lived, my life might have been different.
It might not then have been the failure which it has been.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: Yes, sir, it has been a complete and utter failure!
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: Young man, marry-marry. I do not say marry for your own happiness, though Heaven knows I am a proof of the truth of my words, dying here alone and almost friendless!-but marry for the good you may accomplish in the world and the happiness you may give others.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: I made one mistake, sir, early in life, and it has lasted me ever since. I put Brains before everything, Intellect before Heart. It was all selfishness: that was the rock on which I split. I was a man of parts, sir, and I thought that with my intellect I could do everything. But I could not.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: Young man, were you ever in love?
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: Young man, treasure it-treasure it as your life. I was in love once-really in love only once-and I believed I had my happiness in my own hands, and I flung it away, and wrecked my life.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: And I simply flung away salvation!
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: I am not speaking groundlessly, for I was not even left the poor consolation of doubt as to whether I should have succeeded. When at last I awoke from my besotted condition my chance was gone. The woman for whom I had given up the one I loved, because I thought she would advance me in life, proved as shallow and heartless as I was myself, and, after I had made my plans and prepared my house for her, threw me over remorselessly for what she deemed a better match, and married a rich fool; and when at length I went back to the woman I loved and offered her my heart, which, indeed, had always been hers, she had given hers to another.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: She told me that she had cared for me once, and might have married me had I spoken; but that time was long past, and she now loved another better than she had ever loved me.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: Cultivate the affections, young man: cultivate the affections. Take an old man's word for it, that the men who are happy are those who love and are loved. Better love the meanest thing that lives than only yourself. Even as a matter of policy it is best. I had the best intellect of any young man of my time and set, and I have seen men with half my brains, under the inspiration of love and the obligations and duties it creates, go forward to success which I could never achieve. Whilst I was narrowing and drying up, they were broadening and reaching out in every direction. Often I have gone along the street and envied the poorest man I met with his children on their holiday strolls. My affections had been awakened, but too late in life; and I could not win friendship then. That child that you had in your arms the day I met you was the first child I had seen in years who looked at me without either fear or repugnance.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: So you took my advice and picked a girl out of that very carriage, did you?
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: Whose carriage was it, and what was her name, if you do not mind telling an old man?
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: Oh, no matter; don't feel obliged to tell me.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: It was the 'Hill-and-Dale' carriage, and her name is 'Elizabeth Dale.'
speaker: narrator

utterance: Elizabeth Dale?
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: How strange!
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: Has she beauty?
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: I think she has, and others think so, too. I believe you do yourself.
speaker: narrator

utterance: How is that? I have never seen her.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: Do you remember your hat blowing off one day last spring on Richardson Street, and a young girl running out of a house, bareheaded, and catching it for you? Well, that was Elizabeth Dale.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Was it, indeed? I ought to have known it, she looked so like her! Only I thought it was simply her beauty which made the resemblance. All youth and beauty coupled with sweetness have brought up Elizabeth Green to me through the years,
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: And the child who offered you the bread and jam that day was her nephew.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Indeed!
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: Do you think she would come and see me?
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: Cannot you bring her?
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: Why, I do not know-Yes, I suppose she would come with me,-only-only-. Why, yes, I could see if she would.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Ask her to come and see an old man who has not long to stay here, and who wishes to see the girl whom you are going to marry.
speaker: Basham Miles

speaker: William Kemp

utterance: Somewhar in he ole secketary. He writ it not long ago, an' he tole me he had put it in dyah for you, and I wuz to tell you 'bout it when he died. He said dat would tell all 'bout de 'rangements for de funeral an' ev'thing. He knowed he wuz gwine, suh, better 'n we all.
speaker: William Kemp

utterance: My dear, did you ever hear your mother speak of me?
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: I cannot remember that I ever did.
speaker: Elizabeth Dale

utterance: She may have done it, you know, without my recollecting it, for I was a heedless young thing.
speaker: Elizabeth Dale

utterance: I am not surprised.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: My dear, I used to be in love with your mother, and I never loved any one else. I was most unworthy of her. But I have carried her image in my heart all these years.
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance:
I want you now to grant me a favor-I want you to let me come again?-To-morrow?
-Will you?
speaker: Elizabeth Dale

utterance: God bless you!
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: God bless you!
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: God bless you!
speaker: Basham Miles

utterance: That poor old man!
speaker: Elizabeth Dale

utterance: Go in there, Mr. Clark, and tell him we want to go home,
speaker: one youth

utterance: Oh! He'll be out directly now,
speaker: John Clark

utterance: You 've been saying that for three hours!
speaker: one youth

utterance: Well, see if it does n't come true this time,'
speaker: John Clark

utterance: He'll make it up to you.
speaker: John Clark

utterance: I'm going to give him notice. I'll not be put upon this way-
speaker: a yet younger clerk

utterance: Yes, you will!
speaker: the older grumbler

utterance: He'll be through directly, see if he is not,
speaker: John Clark

utterance: Don't make a noise, there's a good fellow;
speaker: John Clark

utterance: He must be writing his love-letters. Go in there, Hartley, and help him out. You 're an adept at that,
speaker: the youngster

utterance: But you are already rich-you must be worth half a million! and you are a single man, with no children to leave it to.
speaker: Henry Trelane

utterance: Yes, but I mean to be worth double that.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Why?
speaker: Henry Trelane

utterance: Oh!-so that I can tell any man I choose to go to the d- -l,
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Well, that is not much of a satisfaction after all,
speaker: Henry Trelane

utterance: the real satisfaction is in helping him the other way;
speaker: Henry Trelane

utterance: Oh!-Mr. Clark, I did not know I should have been so long about my work. I was so engaged getting my book straight for you, and writing a few cheques for my annual contributions to hospitals, etc.,-that the time slipped by-
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Oh! that's all right, Mr. Livingstone,
speaker: John Clark

utterance: Shall I have these mailed or sent by a messenger?
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Mail them, of course,
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: And Clark, I want you to-
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: I thought possibly that, as to-morrow is-
speaker: John Clark

utterance: I have been going over my matters, and they are in excellent shape-better this year than ever before-
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: That 's very good. I knew they were.
speaker: John Clark

utterance: Yes, very good, indeed, And I have got everything straight for you this year; and I want you to come up to my house this evening and go over the books with me quietly, so that I can show you-
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: This evening?
speaker: John Clark

utterance: Yes, this evening. I shall be at home this evening and to-morrow evening-Why not this evening?
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Why, only-that it 's-However,-I'll be there, sir. About eight-thirty, I suppose?
speaker: John Clark

utterance: Yes,
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: I expect to pay you,
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Oh! it was not that!-It was-I'll be there,
speaker: John Clark

utterance: Believe he 's gone to the telephone,
speaker: the younger clerks

utterance: Guess who it is?
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: Blue Beard
speaker: John Clark

utterance: No-o!
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: Queen Victoria?
speaker: John Clark

utterance: No-o-o!
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: Mary, Queen of Scots?-I know it 's a queen.
speaker: John Clark

utterance: No. Now you are not guessing-It is n't any queen, at all.
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: Yes, I am-Oh! I know-Santa Claus.
speaker: John Clark

utterance: No; but somebody 'at knows about him.
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: Mr. L-m-m-
speaker: John Clark

utterance: No!
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: Now, if you guess right this time, you'll get a reward?
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: What reward?
speaker: John Clark

utterance: Why,-Santa Claus will bring you a whole lot of nice-
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: I don't believe that;-he will be too busy with some other folks I know, who-
speaker: John Clark

utterance: No, he won't-I know he 's going to bring you-Oh! And besides, I'll give you a whole lot of kisses.
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: Oh! yes, I know-the Princess with the Golden Locks, Santa Claus's Partner-the sweetest little kitten in the world, and her name is-Kitty Clark.
speaker: John Clark

utterance: Umhm-m!
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: Oh! papa!
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: But papa you must come-You promised!
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: That sliding, back there, must be stopped. It is a nuisance,
speaker: Livingstone

utterance:
Here, I am going to see that you stop that sliding and enforce the law, or I shall report you for failure to perform your duty. I see your number
-268.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: All right, sir. You can do as you please about that,
speaker: the officer

utterance: This gentleman has complained. and you must stop,
speaker: the officer

utterance: Arr-oh-h! We ain't a-hurtin' him! What's he got to do wid us anyhow!
speaker: the boys

utterance: He ain't no gentleman-a gentleman don't never interfere wid poor little boys what ain't a-done him no harm!
speaker: the boys

utterance: Be off. Go to the Associated Charities,
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Go where, sir?
speaker: A red-faced, collarless man

utterance: Go to the devil!
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: For five cents,
speaker: the ragged, meager boy

utterance: James!
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Yes, sir. Have you dined, sir?
speaker: James

utterance: Dined? No, of course not! Where was I to dine?
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: I thought perhaps you had dined at the club. I will have dinner directly, sir,
speaker: James

utterance: Dine at the club! Why should I dine at the club? Have n't I my own house to dine in?
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Yes, sir. We had dinner ready, only-as you were so late we thought perhaps you were dining at the club. You had not said anything about dining out.
speaker: James

utterance: What is that?
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Ahem! I thinks they 's the laundress's, sir. They just came around this evening-
speaker: James

utterance: Well! I-!
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Go down and send them and her off immediately; and you-I wish some dinner,
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Yes, sir.
speaker: James

utterance: Shall you be dining at home to-morrow, sir?
speaker: James

utterance: Yes, of course,
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: And I don't want to see any one to-night, no matter who comes. I am tired.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Yes, sir.
speaker: James

utterance: I don't want any dinner.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Can have it for you directly, sir,
speaker: James

utterance: I say, I don't want any.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Are you feeling bad, sir?
speaker: James

utterance: No, I only want to be let alone. I shall go out presently to the club.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Wait till you 've known a man twenty years before you marry him, and then you'll never marry him,
speaker: the cook

utterance: Mr. Livingstone begs to be excused this evening, sir,
speaker: James

utterance: Yes.
speaker: John Clark

utterance: He says he regrets he cannot see any one,
speaker: James

utterance: Yes. That's all right. I know.
speaker: John Clark

utterance: No, sir. He cannot see anybody at all this evening,
speaker: James

utterance: Why, he told me to come and bring his books! I suppose he meant-!
speaker: John Clark

utterance: No, sir. He is not very well this evening.
speaker: James

utterance: Not well! Why, he left the office only an hour or two ago.
speaker: John Clark

utterance: Yes, sir; but he walked up, and seemed very tired when he arrived. He did not eat anything, and-the doctor is coming to see him.
speaker: James

utterance: He has been working too hard,
speaker: John Clark

utterance: He ought to have let me go over those accounts. With all he has to carry!
speaker: Mr. Clark

utterance: Yes, sir, that 's it.
speaker: James

utterance: Well, don't you think I 'd better go up and see him?
speaker: Mr. Clark

utterance: I might be able to suggest something?
speaker: Mr. Clark

utterance: No, sir. He said quite positive he would not see anybody.
speaker: James

utterance: I was afraid something might 'ave 'appened down in the-ah-?
speaker: James

utterance: No, indeed. It 's nothing like that, James.
speaker: Mr. Clark

utterance: We never had so good a year. You can make your mind easy about that.
speaker: Mr. Clark

utterance: Thank you, sir.
speaker: James

utterance: We'll have the doctor drop in to see him, and I hope he 'll be all right in the morning. Snowy night, sir.
speaker: James

utterance: I hope so.
speaker: Mr. Clark

utterance: You'll let me know if I am wanted-if I can do anything. I will come around first thing in the morning to see how he is. I hope he 'll be all right. Good-night. A merry Christmas to you.
speaker: Mr. Clark

utterance: Good-night, sir. Thankee, sir; the same to you, sir. I 'm going to wait up to see how he is. Good-night, sir.
speaker: James

utterance: How did I come?'-Ran every step of the way.-'Why did I come back?'-Well! that 's a question for a man with eight children who will sit up and keep Santa Claus out of the house unless their father comes home and puts them to bed and holds their eyelids down to keep them from peeping and scaring Santa Claus away!
speaker: John Clark

utterance: What did Mr. Livingstone say?'-Well what do you suppose a man would say Christmas Eve to another man who had eight wideawake children who will sit up in front of the biggest fire-place in the house until midnight Christmas Eve so that Santa Claus can't come down the only chimney big enough to hold his presents? He would say, 'John Clark, I have no children of my own, but you have eight, and if you don't go home this minute and see that those children are in bed and fast asleep and snoring,—yes, snoring, mind,-by ten o'clock, I'll never, and Santa Claus will never-!'
speaker: John Clark

utterance: 'Did I see anything of Santa Claus?'
speaker: John Clark

utterance: Well, if I were to tell you-what I saw this night, why,—you 'd never believe me. There's a sleigh so big coming in a little while to this town, and this street, and this house, that it holds presents enough for—.
speaker: John Clark

utterance: When will it be here?' Well, from the sleigh-bells that I heard I should say. My goodness, gracious! If it is n't almost ten o'clock, and if that sleigh should get here whilst there's a single eye open in this house, I don't know what Santa Claus might do!
speaker: John Clark

utterance: Mr. Livingstone was feeling unwell
speaker: Mr. Clark

utterance: Shall you be dining at home to-morrow?
speaker: James

utterance: Why, Livingstone, you have told me of your home and your horses, but never told me of your father and mother. Do you know that they are the best in the world?
speaker: Henry Trelane

utterance: Livingstone, I like you, but I love your father.
speaker: Henry Trelane's friend

utterance: My boy, learn the pleasure of giving.
speaker: Livingstone's father

utterance: Why do you do that?
speaker: some one

utterance: He perhaps has parts, but he is a young man and wholly unknown.
speaker: some one

utterance: That is the very reason I do it. Those who are known need no assistance. Help young men, for thereby some have helped angels unawares.
speaker: Livingstone's father

utterance: Yes, but it's not anything Santa Claus can give. I have asked God for it.
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: What?
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Something to make mamma well: to help papa pay for the house. He says it 's that 'at keeps her ill, and she says if she were well he could pay for it: and I just pray to God for it every day.
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: Well, let's take a sleigh-ride and see if any other shops are open. Then we can return.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: But you say you have n't money enough with you, and I don't know you?
speaker: Mr. Brown

utterance: Why, man, I am worth- I am worth enough to buy all this square and not feel it.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: That may be all so, but I don't know you. Do you know anybody in this part of the town?
speaker: Mr. Brown

utterance: Well, I know Mr. Clark. He would vouch for me, but-
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Kitty, you know this gentleman, you say?
speaker: Mr. Brown

utterance: Yes. Oh, he 's all right. He's my papa's employer and he gave him fifty dollars last Christmas, 'cause my papa told me so.'
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: Business is business, you know?
speaker: Mr. Brown

utterance: He 's an awful kind man. He has n't got any little children of his own, and he 's going to give things to little poor children. He always does that, I guess.
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: Well, no, I don't, but I wish I had, and I'll pay you.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: All right. She knows you and that will do.
speaker: Mr. Brown

utterance: Where are we going, Mr. Livingstone?
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: Just where you like.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: To the Children's Hospital.
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: To the Children's Hospital, driver.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: We'll play you 're Santa Claus.
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: No. Play you are Santa Claus's partner.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: And you?
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: You are not to say anything about me.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: You have to ring at the side door at night.
speaker: the driver

utterance: When they open the door, you are to do all the talking.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Who shall I say rang?
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: Santa Claus's partner.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: But you-?
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: No. You are not to mention my name. Remember!
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Who's there?
speaker: the porter

utterance: Santa Claus's partner.
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: What do you want? We don't take in anything at this hour except patients.
speaker: the porter

utterance: Who is it?
speaker: the matron

utterance: Santa Claus's partner.
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: What do you want, dear?
speaker: the matron

utterance: To leave some presents for the children.
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: What children?
speaker: the matron

utterance: All the good children-all the sick children, I mean-all the children.
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: Come in.
speaker: the matron

utterance: Christ is born. You heard the bells?
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: It's all done, and I prayed so hard that not one of them stirred, and now when they wake they'll think it was real Santa Claus. They say he always comes at twelve and I counted the clocks.-I wonder if he went home?
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: I'm sure of it.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: I think we'd better go home now.
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Santa Claus's partner.
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: The same to you, your honor; the same to you sir. We 've had a good time to-night, sir, have n't we? And I wish you many more like it, sir. And when Christmas comes along next time I hope you'll remember me, for I'll remember you; I've had a little child in that 'ere same horspital. God took her to Himself twelve years ago. They're good to 'em there, rich and poor all alike; and 't is n't every night I can drive 'Santa Claus's partner.'
speaker: the driver

utterance: When we found you had gone out, sir, we were afraid you might be sick, and the cook has got something hot for you?
speaker: James

utterance: We thought we would try to make the house look a little cheery, sir. Hope you don't mind, sir?
speaker: James

utterance: Mind! I am delighted; and I thank you very much. Mind? I should think not!
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Allow you!
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: I give you carte blanche, only have everything ready by five o'clock.-Ask the cook to send up whatever she has; I'm hungry, and we 'll talk it over whilst I'm taking supper.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Yes, sir; yes, sir; yes, sir;
speaker: James

utterance: Tell the laundress to be sure and bring her children around to-morrow, and be sure you make them have a good time.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Yes, sir.
speaker: James

utterance: And ascertain where policeman, No. 268, is to be found to-morrow. I want to send a contribution to make a good slide for some boys on his beat.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Yes, sir.
speaker: James

utterance: I love you.
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: Let's go and have a game of blind-man's buff. I am beginning to feel young again.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Well, this is my final triumph over Will.
speaker: Mrs. Wright

utterance: You know Will has always been very fond of you, and he says you have been working too hard of late and have not been looking well. When I did n't get my usual contributions from you this Christmas I didn't know what to make of it, but I think that on my round this morning I have found out the reason?
speaker: Mrs. Wright

utterance: Will was sure he saw you in the club last night, and he tried to catch you, but you ran off; and now I have come for you and will take no refusal.
speaker: Mrs. Wright

utterance: I am having a Christmas dinner myself.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Then you will come in after they go?
speaker: Mrs. Wright

utterance: What a pleasant-looking man, and what lovely children! That little girl,—I thought it was Cupid when she had the bandage on her eyes, and now I am sure of it.
speaker: Mrs. Wright

utterance: Let me present them to you.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: I did not know you had a partner?
speaker: Mrs. Wright

utterance: It is my Christmas gift from Santa Claus. One of them; I have many.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: Nonsense! Clark, I am not giving you anything. I am paying.-I mean, I owe you everything, and what I don't owe you, I owe Kitty. Last night you lent me-
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: It was more than even you knew, Clark, and I'll owe you a debt of gratitude all my life. All I ask is, that you will forget the past and help me in the future and sometimes lend me Kitty. I never knew until now how good it was to have a partner.
speaker: Livingstone

utterance: I love you.
speaker: Clark's little girl

utterance: I think I've heard of you before.
speaker: Mrs. Wright
